en.sm-observation_def: Observation: a statement based on something you have seen, heard, or noticed.
en.sm-observation_desc: Make an observation about a phenomenon (something that exists or has happened).
en.sm-question_def: Scientific Question: a question that can be answered with empirical evidence.
en.sm-question_desc: Ask a scientific question based on your observations.
en.sm-hypothesis_def: Hypothesis: an educated guess of the answer to your scientific question.
en.sm-hypothesis_desc: Make a hypothesis based on your observations and science knowledge.
en.sm-experiment_def: Experiment: a test that changes one variable to observe what happens to another.
en.sm-experiment_desc: Plan and conduct an experiment to test your hypothesis.
en.sm-analysis_def: Analysis: a review of your data to find patterns or relationships.
en.sm-analysis_desc: Analyze the data from your experiment.
en.sm-conclusion_def: Conclusion: a summary statement that compares your hypothesis with the results of the experiment.
en.sm-conclusion_desc: Make a conclusion based on the results from your experiment and analysis.

en.item_desc_pg:
An instrument for measuring underwater pressure.
Returns values in atm units, where 1 atm = the atmospheric pressure at sea level.
en.item_desc_dg:
An instrument for measuring underwater depth.
Measures pressure then calculates depth using their linear relationship. Returns values in meters.
en.item_desc_th:
A device for measuring water temperature.
Returns values in Celsius.
en.desc_shell:
A large sea snail with a horn-shaped shell.
There is something mysterious about this one...
en.desc_otter:
A cute marine mammal with thick fur.
Can live on land and in water.
en.intro-1: Have you ever heard of the Triton Triangle?
en.intro-1.1-1: It is a beautiful and mysterious place in the ocean.
en.intro-1.1-2: No one has ever fully explored the depths before.
en.intro-2: I'm going there on an expedition.
en.intro-2.1: Really! Can I come with you?
en.intro-2.1-3: I'll take you one day... might be too dangerous for you now.
en.intro-3: The Triton Triangle is known for stories about sea monsters, strange forces...
en.intro-4: ...and something hidden deep below, a treasure...
en.intro-5: I don't know kid, true scientists don't just listen to stories...
en.intro-6: We find out the truth, and learn about the world around us by following a process.
en.intro-7: A process called the The Scientific Method.
en.newspaper-text-1: Renowned marine scientist Dr. Conch, and his submarine SM-Explorer, has gone missing since deep-sea expedition into the Triton Triangle.
en.newspaper-text-2: Search teams found wreckage of his ship, but no sign of him or his submarine, the SM-Explorer.
en.newspaper-text-3: After weeks of searching, the search mission was called off due to 'strange forces' and failing communications.
en.radio_no-signal: There is no signal here... maybe I should try again above water.
en.radio_signal-lost: Weird... lost the signal. Just when I was about to report something interesting.
en.tut_status-1: Mission Control, this is SM-Explorer-2. Do you copy?
en.tut_status-2: SM-Explorer-2, we hear you loud and clear. What's your status?
en.tut_status-3: I have arrived at the Triton Triangle.
en.tut_status-4: It really is beautiful here... just like how my dad described.
en.tut_status-5: Copy that. Please stay safe out there.
en.tut_mb-1: Your mission is to explore, and collect data in the depths of the Triton Triangle.
en.tut_mb-1.1: How should I approach the mission?
en.tut_sm-1: Your best chance to succeed is to learn and understand the deep ocean.
en.tut_sm-2: You can use the Scientific Method steps as a guideline for your exploration.
en.tut_data.ql-1: Qualitative data are descriptions of things that are observed but not measured precisely.
en.tut_data.ql-2: For example, observations of color, sounds, behavior, etc.
en.tut_data.ql-3: They are useful, but sometimes can be biased.
en.tut_data.qn-1: Quantitative data are precise measurements that can be counted or measured.
en.tut_data.qn-2: For example, measuring variables like depth, pressure, temperature, etc. during an experiment.
en.tut_data.qn-3: They require specific tools and instruments to measure, but provide more accurate data.
en.tut_data.ok-1: Great. Collecting both types of data is known as gathering empirical evidence.
en.tut_data.ok-2: Recording empirical evidence is how we can repeat and verify our findings with each other.
en.tut_mb-1.3: Copy that. I'm ready to explore.
en.tut_info-1: Very well. On the last search mission, we found wreckage of your dad's ship...
en.tut_info-2: ... but there was no sign of him or his submarine.
en.tut_info-4: Also nearby is a kelp forest, but we were not able to get very far...
en.tut_info-5: Equipment started to malfunction, and there were reports of strange creatures...
en.tut_info-6: We suspect it gets much deeper there...
en.tut_info-8: Call us whenever need a recap. Good luck, SM-Explorer-2.
en.tut_data.ql-5: Past the kelp forest, lies an even deeper abyss.
en.tut_data.ql-6: They suspect that is where your dad went missing.
en.tut_data.ql-7: I see, what did they find there?
en.tut_brief2: Your mission is to explore, and collect data about the depths of the Triton Triangle.
en.tut_brief2_o1: What do we know about this place?
en.tut_story1: To be honest, we don't know much except for the spooky stories.
en.tut_story2: Years ago, a crew ventured to the Triangle to hunt for a treasure.
en.tut_story3: Sailors warned them not to disrupt the depths, but they didn't listen.
en.tut_story5_o1: Yeah... my dad was part of that crew.
en.tut_map1: Maybe I'll find some clues about what happened to him.
en.tut_map2: I see... I'm sorry about your dad.
en.tut_map3: The only thing we recovered from the wrecks was a drawing.
en.tut_map4: Some parts are missing, but it looks like a map of the depths of the Triangle.
en.tut_brief2_o2: How should I approach the mission?
en.tut_sm1: I recommend using the Scientific Method to guide your exploration.
en.tut_sm2: The Scientific Method is a process that scientists follow to learn about the world around us.
en.tut_sm3: Use these steps as a guideline:
en.tut_sm4: Your best chance to succeed is to learn and understand the deep ocean.
en.tut_brief2_o3: Copy that. I'm ready to start.
en.tut_brief3: Great. Let's do a practice dive in the wrecks first.

en.tut_task2: Record 3 observations about things that change with depth.
en.tut_task3: Contact us with the radio when you're done. Good luck, SM-Explorer.

en.radio1_o-hi: All good here. Just saying hi.
en.radio1_o-hi1: Good to hear from you. Feel free to radio in whenever you need.
en.radio1_o-repeat: Can you repeat what you said earlier?
en.tut_observations1: Sunlight is visible near the surface.
en.tut_observations2: The colors look different when I .
en.tut_observations3: It is much darker at the deep end.
en.tut_review-1: Signal received SM-Explorer. How did you go?
en.tut_review-2: Nice work. These observations are an example of qualitative data.
en.tut_review-3: Which are descriptions about things that you observed, but did not measure precisely.
en.tut_review-3_o1: Was I suppose to do precise measurements?
en.tut_review-4: Not necessarily. Collecting qualitative data is always a good start.
en.tut_review-5: However, simply making descriptions about things can sometimes be biased.
en.tut_review-6: We can also collect quantitative data by making precise measurements.
en.tut_review-7: This is also known as gathering empirical evidence.
en.tut_smOld: A Scientific Method exploration involves asking questions, and answering them with empirical evidence.
en.tut_o1: Sure. If you want to learn more about something you observed...
en.tut_q1: ...the next step is to ask a scientific question: a question that can be answered with empirical evidence.
en.tut_q2: For example, based on your observations, you might ask:
en.tut_h1: How does the color of the ocean change with depth in the ocean?... what would your guess to the answer be?
en.tut_h1_o1: It doesn't change. It's always blue.
en.tut_h1_o2: It gets more colorful the deeper you go.
en.tut_h1_o3: It gets darker the deeper you go.
en.tut_h2: Interesting. Well, the guess you just made is called a hypothesis.
en.tut_e1: After making a hypothesis, you check if it is correct by testing it with an experiment.
en.tut_e2: For example, you could conduct an experiment by recording precise measurements of the color at each depth.
en.tut_a1: With the empirical evidence you have collected...
en.tut_a2: ...analyze the data to see if it supports your hypothesis.
en.tut_c1: Then finally, draw a conclusion that summarises your results.
en.tut_c2: This is the process of a Scientific Method exploration.
en.tut_sm_o2: I see. I'm ready to continue my exploration.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-1: These are dangerous waters. Turn back now, for your own good.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-1_o1: What?! A talking shell! That is so cool.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-1_o1-1: Hey, are you even listening? ...and don't call me a shell.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-2: Many treasure hunters have come, and never returned to their families.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-3: Trust me. Leave now while you still can.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-3_o1: Ok, but I will be back.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-3_o2: I can't leave now. Not until I complete my mission.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-3_o2-1: I'm not a treasure hunter. I'm an ocean explorer... and a scientist.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-3_o2-2: I'm here to explore the depths of this place, and find out what happened to my dad.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-3_o2-4: My dad was a scientist. He came here years ago and went missing.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-3_o2-6: I see... I'm sorry about your dad...
en.ch1_conch-encounter-4: Listen kid... the depths are full of wonders, but also dangers.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-5: To survive, you must first understand the world around you. Only then might you find the answers you seek.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-6: Start with the first step of the Scientific Method:
en.ch1_conch-encounter-7: Come back once you have recorded 3 observations about things that change with depth.
en.ch1_conch-encounter-7_o1-1: Explore this place, both shallow and deep; try to observe any changes and record them.
en.ch1_conch-review-1: Nice, these observations are examples of qualitative data.
en.ch1_conch-review-1_o1-1: You made some descriptions of things without measuring them precisely right?
en.ch1_conch-review-2: We can now move on to the next step of the Scientific Method:
en.ch1_conch-review-4: What could be a scientific question I could ask based on these observations?
en.ch1_conch-review-4_q1: Why is the deep ocean so dark?
en.ch1_conch-review-4_q1-1: Good start, but it needs to be more specific.
en.ch1_conch-review-4_q1-2: In your question, try to use variables: things that can be counted or measured.
en.ch1_conch-review-4_q2: How does color of the ocean change with depth?
en.ch1_conch-review-4_q2-1: That's better, but color can sometimes be subjective.
en.ch1_conch-review-4_q2-2: Hmm, if we used a different variable, something less subjective...
en.ch1_conch-review-4_q3: How about the amount of sunlight?
en.ch1_conch-review-4_q3-1: Yes, that works! How does the amount of sunlight change with depth in the ocean?
en.ch1_conch-review-4_q3-2: Now that is a question that relates to your observations, is specific, and can be measured.
en.ch1_conch-review-6: These are examples of qualitative data: descriptions about things that are observed, but not measured precisely.
